{{More citations needed|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox automobile |name=Ford Expedition |image= '18 Ford Expedition Max.jpg |caption = 2018 Ford Expedition MAX |manufacturer=[[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] |production=1996–present |model_years=1997–present |class=[[Full-size car|Full-size]] [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] |related=[[Lincoln Navigator]] |body_style=4-door [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] |layout={{unbulleted list | [[Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive]] | [[Front-engine, four-wheel-drive layout|Front-engine, four-wheel-drive]] }} |weight= {{convert|5801|lb|abbr=on}} (standard)
{{convert|6071|lb|abbr=on}} (EL){{cite web |url=http://consumerguideauto.howstuffworks.com/2009-ford-expedition-3.htm |title=2009 Ford Expedition Safety |publisher=Consumer Guide |date= |accessdate=2009-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503185158/http://consumerguideauto.howstuffworks.com/2009-ford-expedition-3.htm |archivedate=2009-05-03 |df= }} |predecessor=[[Ford Bronco]] }} The '''Ford Expedition''' is a [[Full-size car|Full-size]] [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] manufactured by [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]]. Introduced for the 1997 model year as the successor of the [[Ford Bronco]], the Expedition was the first full-size Ford SUV sold with a four-door body. For its entire production life, the Ford Expedition has been derived from the corresponding generation of the Ford F-150 in production, sharing some body and mechanical components. The fourth-generation Ford Expedition began production for the 2018 model year. Similar to the configuration of the [[Chevrolet Tahoe]] and [[Chevrolet Suburban|Suburban]], the Ford Expedition is sold in regular and extended lengths (the Ford Expedition EL/Max); sold since 2007, the latter functionally serves as the replacement for the [[Ford Excursion]]. Since 1997, the Lincoln division has marketed the Ford Expedition as the [[Lincoln Navigator]], the first full-size SUV sold by a luxury auto brand in North America (the Expedition was never sold as a [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]]). The third Ford vehicle to use the Expedition nameplate, the full-size SUV follows a 1992 F-150 Eddie Bauer concept vehicle and a 1995 trim level package on the two-door [[Ford Explorer Sport]]. Prior to 2009, the Ford Expedition was assembled at the [[Michigan Assembly Plant]] in [[Wayne, Michigan]] (previously home to the Ford Bronco)., After 2009, the Ford Expedition was moved to the [[Kentucky Truck Assembly|Kentucky Truck Plant]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. ==Vehicle background== The Expedition offered up to nine-passenger seating in model years before 2009 (with a front bench seat option in the first row); 2009–present has bucket seats in the first row and seats eight passengers.{{cite web|title=Ford Expedition Review|url= http://www.edmunds.com/ford/expedition/}} It is equipped with a [[V8 engine]]. It is similar to the [[Lincoln Navigator]], especially in ''Limited'' (2005–present) or ''King Ranch'' (2005–2017) high-end trims; both of which were introduced for the 2005 model year. With the 2011 model year, the base model was designated XL, an upgraded XLT, and new for 2011 XLT Premium that replaced the [[Eddie Bauer]] trim (1997–2010) which was phased out from the entire Ford vehicle lineup. As of 2010, over 1,545,241 Expeditions (both standard and EL/Max) have been sold. A modified ''Special Service Vehicle'' version is available for [[law enforcement agencies]], [[Firefighting worldwide|fire departments]], and [[emergency medical services]]. The Ford Expedition is also known for being one of the longest-lasting vehicles on the road. With 5% of vehicles over 200K miles, it landed the #4 spot in a 2016 study by [[iSeeCars.com]] listing the top 10 longest-lasting vehicles. The Expedition is also the last current Ford vehicle to retain its classic older look from the late 1990s and early-mid 2000s Ford vehicles with its triangular-styled taillamps and rounded-rectangular shaped headlamps along with the overall boxy shape of the body.{{cite web|url=http://blog.iseecars.com/2016/03/03/longest-lasting-vehicles-2016/ |title=Longest Lasting Vehicles Over 200,000 Miles – 2016 Study Shows Top 10 Consists of Mostly Trucks and SUVs |website=Blog.iseecars.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}} ==First generation (1997–2002)== {{Infobox automobile |name=First generation (UN93) |image=97-98 Ford Expedition.jpg |production=July 22, 1996 – March 2002 |model_years=1997–2002 |engine= 4.6 L ''[[Ford Modular engine#2-valve|Triton 16V]]'' [[V8 engine|V-8]]
5.4 L ''[[Ford Modular engine#2-valve 2|Triton 16V]]'' V-8 |wheelbase=1996–98: {{convert|119.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1998–2002: {{convert|119.1|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length={{convert|204.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|78.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height=1996–98 4WD: {{convert|76.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1996–98 2WD: {{convert|74.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1998–2000 4WD: {{convert|78.4|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
1998–2000 2WD: {{convert|76.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
2000–02 4WD: {{convert|76.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
2000–02 2WD: {{convert|74.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |transmission=4-speed E4OD [[automatic transmission|automatic]]
4-speed 4R100 automatic
4-speed 4R70W automatic
'''[[Transfer case]]''' (4x4 models)
2-speed BorgWarner 4406
High range [[ratio]]: 1.00:1
Low range ratio: 2.64:1 |platform=[[Ford U platform]] |assembly=[[Wayne, Michigan]], [[United States]] |related=[[Ford F-150]]
[[Lincoln Blackwood]]
[[Lincoln Navigator#First generation (1997–2002)|Lincoln Navigator]] |designer = Bob Aikins (1993) }} [[File:Ford Expedition rear 20071231.jpg|thumb|left|Ford Expedition XLT]] Known internally at Ford as the UN93, the first generation Expedition was developed under the UN93 program from 1993 to 1996, headed by chief engineer Dale Claudepierre at a cost of $1.3 billion USD. Initial planning began in 1991 parallel to PN96 F-Series development, prior to the UN93 program fully being approved in 1993. Styling approval was completed in early 1993 (3 1/2 years ahead of 1996 production) under design chief Bob Aikins, with the UN93 design being frozen by September 1993, at 34 months prior to July 1996 production commencement.{{cite web|url=http://www.planedge.com/forecasting/engineexcerpt.pdf |title=4100 engmy report1 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-07-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2003/2003_expedition.html |title=Ford Truck Enthusiasts - Expedition Overview |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-19}}{{cite web|last1=Connelly|first1=Mary|title=FORD'S EXPEDITION TAKES ON TAHOE, SEEKS CONQUEST SALES|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/19960513/ANA/605130761/fords-expedition-takes-on-tahoe-seeks-conquest-sales|website=Automotive News|publisher=Crain Communications|accessdate=8 February 2017|date=13 May 1996}}{{cite web|title=Ford Has A Bigger Idea: The Expedition|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-05-16/topic/9605140728_1_expedition-ford-motor-ford-explorer|website=Orlando Sentinel|publisher=Detroit Free Press|accessdate=8 February 2017|date=16 May 1996}}{{cite web|last1=Connelly|first1=Mary|title=DANA COMES TO FORD'S AID FOR HOT-SELLING BIG TRUCKS|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/19960805/ANA/608050750?template=print|website=Automotive News|publisher=Crain Communications|accessdate=8 February 2017|date=5 August 1996}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Dale-Claudepierre/23106674 |title=Dale Claudepierre | Formerly Ford Compact Utilities |website=ZoomInfo.com |date=1947-12-09 |accessdate=2017-03-27}} The all-new full-size SUV was unveiled on May 9, 1996 and launched on October 2, 1996 as a 1997 model.{{cite web|last1=Truett|first1=Richard|title=Ford's Big New Baby|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1996-10-03/topic/9610011147_1_expedition-land-rover-range-rover|website=Orlando Sentinel|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=8 February 2017|date=3 October 1996}}{{cite web|last1=Rewey|first1=Bob|title=Ford Reports October U.S. Car and Truck Sales|url=http://www.theautochannel.com/news/press/date/19971104/press007737.html|website=The Auto Channel|publisher=Ford Motor Company|accessdate=8 February 2017|date=4 November 1997}} It replaced the aging two-door [[Ford Bronco]]. The ''XLT'' was the base model. The Expedition featured optional three row seating, first row captains chair seating, available second row captains chair seating, leather seating surfaces, illuminated running boards, heated side view mirrors, power [[moon roof]], dual zone climate control and Ford's Mach audio sound system with rear [[subwoofer]]. Many of these features were standard on the ''[[Eddie Bauer]]'' version. Expedition was available with automatic full-time [[Control Trac|ControlTrac]] four-wheel drive with two-speed dual range BorgWarner 4406 [[transfer case]] and a center [[Electromagnetic clutch|multi-disc differential]]. ControlTrac was introduced in 1995 and included four selectable modes: Two High, Auto, Four High (lock) and Four Low (lock). Two High mode and Auto mode with ''auto-lock'' was not available.[http://www.allbusiness.com/automotive/motor-vehicle-models-sport-utilitys/7273668-1.html]{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} A short- & long-arm (SLA) independent front suspension with speed-sensitive power-assisted steering was combined with a multi-link rear [[live axle]]. Optional equipment included off-road under-body skid-plate protection, ''Traction-Lok'' rear [[limited-slip differential]], and a heavy-duty trailer towing package. Optional was an electronically controlled [[pneumatic]] [[air suspension]] system that would raise and lower the vehicle depending on road and load conditions. The system also included a kneel-down mode for easier ingress and egress, as well as loading cargo,{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2001_expedition.html |title=Ford Truck Enthusiasts - 2001 Expedition Overview |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} Standard was the 4.6 liter Triton V8 with the 5.4 liter version optional. The first generation Expedition was rated as a [[Low Emission Vehicle#Phase 1 - 1994–1999|Low Emission Vehicle]] (LEV).{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2000_expedition.html |title=Ford Truck Enthusiasts - 2000 Expedition Overview |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-27}} The latter engine combined with the heavy-duty trailer towing package and appropriate axle ratio can achieve a [[towing capacity]] of 8,100 lbs (3,674 kg).{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2001_expedition_1.html |title=Ford Truck Enthusiasts - 2001 Expedition Specifications |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2000_expedition_2.html |title=Ford Truck Enthusiasts - 2000 Expedition Features and Options |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} ===Powertrain=== {| class="wikitable" ! rowspan="2" |Engine name ! rowspan="2" |Configuration ! rowspan="2" |Model Year ! colspan="2" |Output ! rowspan="2" |Transmission |- ! Power ! Torque |- | Ford [[Ford Modular engine#4.6 L|''Triton 4.6L 2-valve'' V-8]] |{{Convert|281|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} SOHC 16V V8 | rowspan="2" | 1997–1998 | {{convert|215|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} |{{convert|290|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} | rowspan="4" |4-speed [[Ford AOD transmission#4R70W|''4R70W'']] automatic (1997-2002) 4-speed ''[[Ford C6 transmission#E4OD|E4OD]]'' automatic (1997-1998) 4-speed [[Ford C6 transmission#4R100|''4R100'']] automatic (1998-2002) Transfer case (4x4): 2-speed BorgWarner 4406 High-range: 1:1 Low-range: 2.64:1 |- 16 4.7 Windsor (289 cu in) Valve (PUSHROD) gasoline -LIMITED availability | Ford [[Ford Modular engine#5.4 L|''Triton 5.4L 2-valve'' V-8]] |{{Convert|330|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} SOHC 16V V8 | {{convert|230|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|325|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |- | Ford ''Triton 4.6L 2-valve'' V-8 |{{Convert|281|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} SOHC 16V V8 | rowspan="2" | 1999–2002 | {{convert|230|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} |{{convert|291|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |- | Ford ''Triton 5.4L 2-valve'' V-8 |{{Convert|330|cuin|L|1|abbr=on|order=flip}} SOHC 16V V8 |{{convert|260|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} |{{convert|350|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |} ===Safety and security=== A two air bag [[Supplementary Restraint System|supplementary restraint system]] (SRS) with 2-way occupant protection was standard. The air bags would adjust deployment force depending on crash severity. Features included [[SecuriLock]] with smart key and engine [[immobilizer]], security approach lamps, four-wheel [[anti-lock braking system]] (ABS), side-intrusion door beams, post-crash fuel pump shut-off and three-point safety belts for all rows of seating with tension and locking retractors. An optional four air bag SRS with 4-way occupant protection was available for the 2000–2002 model years. This included seat-mounted [[Torso airbag|side torso side air bags]]. The 2001 model introduced a BeltMinder system to detect when the driver did not have their safety belt secured. {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan=4| [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]] [[NHTSA NCAP|NCAP]] crash scores:{{cite web|url=http://www.safercar.gov/portal/site/safercar/menuitem.db847bd57e3dc1f885dfc38c35a67789/?vgnextoid=c95df2905bf54110VgnVCM1000002fd17898RCRD&vgnextrefresh=1&ID=6198 |title=Home | National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) |publisher=Safercar.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} |- !colspan=2 | 1997–2000 !colspan=2 | 2001–2002 |- | Frontal Driver: | {{Rating|4|5}} | Frontal Driver: | {{Rating|5|5}} |- | Frontal Passenger: | {{Rating|4|5}} | Frontal Passenger: | {{Rating|5|5}} |- | Side Driver: | Not tested | Side Driver: | Not tested |- | Side Rear Passenger: | Not tested | Side Rear Passenger: | Not tested |- | Rollover [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/resistance Resistance] ([[Rear-wheel-drive|RWD]]): | Not tested | Rollover Resistance ([[Rear-wheel-drive|RWD]]): | {{Rating|2|5}} |- | Rollover Resistance ([[4WD]]): | Not tested | Rollover Resistance ([[4WD]]): | {{Rating|2|5}} |} ===Model year changes=== {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2016}} ====1998==== No major cosmetic or mechanical changes. A new exterior color was added: Wedgewood Blue. Limited availability for 4.6 Windsor versus Romeo engine. This limited run was available only for Ultimate Tow Package ====1999==== [[File:99-02 Ford Expedition .jpg|thumb|right|1999–2002 facelift]] The 1999 model year received a facelift similar to that of the 1999 model year [[Ford F-Series#Tenth generation (1997–2003)|Ford F-150]]. Included in the update was a new front grille which now dropped lower in the center, grille work, as well as a new front bumper that incorporated the fog lamps into the lower valance and larger center air intake. Both the 4.6 liter and 5.4 liter V8 engines received updates including more power and torque. The Two High mode for automatic full-time ControlTrac four-wheel drive equipped models was dropped leaving only Auto, Four High (lock) and Four Low (lock) modes. The dashboard also received an updated radio and air conditioning controls and revised Gauge Cluster and a Digital Odometer for the first time. [[File:1999_Ford_Expedition.jpg|thumb|1999 Eddie Bauer Expedition]] ====2000==== Available features on 2000 models included a hidden radio antenna (integrated into the rear quarter panel window glass), [[Gentex]] auto dimming [[electrochromatic]] rearview mirrors, [[Turn signals#Side marker lights and reflectors|lane departure indicators]] on side view mirrors (before on the glass) and [[ultrasonic sensor|ultrasonic]] rear park assist /backup sensors. The lower front bumper valance and illuminated running boards were changed over to Arizona beige to complement the standard Arizona beige exterior body trim on Eddie Bauer models. ''Estate Green Clearcoat Metallic'' replaces ''Spruce Green Clearcoat Metallic'', and ''Arizona Beige Metallic'' replaces ''Harvest Gold Clearcoat Metallic'' in the color palette. ====2001==== New trim packages included the ''XLT'' model. XLT versions could be optioned with the ''XLT No Boundaries'' package that included monochromatic black paint work with chrome grille and special alloy wheels. Eddie Bauer versions could be optioned with the ''Eddie Bauer Premier'' package that included either [[monochromatic]] Arizona beige or solid black paint work with painted alloy wheels and upgraded leather seating. ====2002==== No major cosmetic or mechanical changes. Last year model for the UN93. This was also the last model year for XLT No Boundaries and Eddie Bauer Premier trims. {{-}} ==Second generation (2003–2006)== {{Infobox automobile |name=Second generation (U222) |image=03-06 Ford Expedition EB.jpg |production=March 2002–July 2006 |model_years=2003–2006 |engine=4.6 L ''[[Ford Modular engine#2-valve|Triton 16V]]'' [[V8 engine|V-8]]
5.4 L ''[[Ford Modular engine#2-valve 2|Triton 16V]]/[[Ford Modular engine#3-valve 2|24V]]'' V-8 |wheelbase={{convert|119.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length={{convert|205.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|78.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height=2005–06 4WD: {{convert|76.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
2005–06 2WD: {{convert|76.7|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
2002–04: {{convert|77.6|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |transmission=4-speed 4R70W [[Automatic transmission|automatic]]
4-speed 4R75E automatic

'''[[Transfer case]]''' (4x4 models)

2-speed BorgWarner 4416
High range [[ratio]]: 1.00:1
Low range ratio: 2.62:1 |platform=[[Ford U platform]] |assembly=[[Wayne, Michigan]], [[United States]] |related=[[Ford F-150]]
[[Lincoln Navigator#Second generation|Lincoln Navigator]] |designer = Tyler Blake (1999){{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/pub/tyler-blake/6/671/925 |title=Tyler Blake |publisher=LinkedIn |date= |accessdate=2015-07-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeforcreativestudies.edu/Alumni/2893/Blake/ |title=Tyler Blake |publisher=Collegeforcreativestudies.edu |date=2015-05-20 |accessdate=2015-07-18}} }} The redesigned second-generation Expedition was developed under the U222 program code name from 1996 to 2002, under Ford chief vehicle engineer Steve von Foerster and chief program engineer [[John Krafcik]] from 1998 to 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/frankquenneville |title=Frank Quenneville |publisher=LinkedIn |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} Design work began in 1997, with a proposal by Tyler Blake being chosen by management and frozen for production in 1999. UN93-body mules were spotted testing in 2000, with full prototypes running from late 2000. The new Expedition was unveiled at the 2002 [[North American International Auto Show]], in January. It was launched in May 2002 for the 2003 model year and featured a new four-wheel independent [[Long travel suspension|long-travel]] suspension system, becoming the first [[full-size]] sport utility vehicle to use a fully independent suspension.{{cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/p/Tyler-Blake/211249436 |title=Tyler Blake | Ford Motor Company |publisher=ZoomInfo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-18}}{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Bob |url=http://www.thecarconnection.com/review/1003712_2003-ford-expedition |title=2003 Ford Expedition Page 1 Review |publisher=The Car Connection |date=2002-04-29 |accessdate=2015-07-18}} The new [[independent rear suspension]] (IRS) was perceived as being controversial by some at the time of its introduction.[http://www.autofieldguide.com/driven/0402dri04.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511231955/http://www.autofieldguide.com/driven/0402dri04.html |date=May 11, 2008 }} A misconception was that the Expedition's towing and off-road capabilities would be reduced, in comparison to the previous generation's rear [[live axle]]. Nevertheless, underbody obstacle clearance improved by half an inch, and up to two inches under the axle differentials.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2003/2003_expedition_2.html |title=Special Features |publisher=www.ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-17}} The new suspension reduces rear unsprung mass by 110 pounds, and allows for a full 9.4 inches of [[suspension travel]] (how much the wheels can travel up or down) improving its ability to traverse uneven terrain for improved control and ride quality.{{cite web|url=http://www.cars.com/ford/expedition/2003/expert-reviews/ |title=2003 Ford Expedition |publisher=Cars.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fourwheeler.com/roadtests/2003/129_0407_2003_ford_expedition/index.html |title=2003 Ford Expedition |publisher=FourWheeler.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-30}} The four-wheel independent long-travel suspension itself is a purpose-built version of race suspensions found on off-road desert race vehicles.{{cite web|url=http://media.ford.com/press_kits_detail.cfm?presskit_id=548&item_id=2408&press_section_id=2871 |title=Expedition Chassis |publisher=media.ford.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130319185555/http://media.ford.com/press_kits_detail.cfm?presskit_id=548&item_id=2408&press_section_id=2871 |archivedate=2013-03-19 |df= }} Towing capacity increased by 800 lbs (363 kg) for a high [[towing capacity]] of 8,900 lbs (4,037 kg) when properly equipped with the appropriate axle ratio and heavy-duty trailer towing package. Payload capacity was increased up to 1,614 lbs (732 kg). Expedition also gained a [[hydroformed]] fully boxed frame providing a 70 percent improvement in torsional stiffness. Along with the high towing capability came all-new steering, braking and electronic systems to help the Expedition better control and maneuver long heavy trailers. Adaptive variable assist power rack-and-pinion steering was introduced along with the largest brake rotors in the segment at that time (13.5 inches up front, 13 inches in back) with brake calipers 100 percent stiffer than the previous generation Expedition. The four-speed 4R70W automatic transmission received all-new control software to allow the transmission to automatically adjust to the demands of towing, using new computer [[logic]] that recognizes changes in load and road conditions. The automatic full-time [[Control Trac|ControlTrac]] four-wheel drive system remained available, with an uprated two-speed dual range BorgWarner 4416 transfer case. The new transfer case featured an updated intelligent locking center multi-disc differential with front-to-rear "[[Torque vectoring|torque biasing]]" capability in Auto mode. A new dedicated [[microprocessor]] with new control software was added allowing the system to detect different [[terrain]] and surface conditions to predict traction loss before it happens. Two High mode was also reintroduced. [[Ford Expedition#Traction Control|Four-wheel electronic traction control]] was now available as an option, and simulated ''front'' and ''rear'' [[Locking differential#Alternatives|differential locks]]. The V8 engines offered on the previous generation were carried over, but not without major changes and improvements. Both the 4.6 and 5.4-liter Triton V8 engines received further refinements in design and overall [[efficiency]]. Expedition qualified as an [[Ultra Low Emission Vehicle]] (ULEV) and was certified under the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] Tier 2 regulations one year earlier than required.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2003/2003_expedition_3.html |title=2002 Ford Expedition Powertrain |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} The 4.6-liter engine received an all-new redesigned cast [[aluminium]] engine block optimized for weight reduction and [[Noise, vibration, and harshness|NVH]] improvements. The 5.4-liter engine received an all-new redesigned cast-iron engine block with computer designed ribbing and bracing, along with thicker side skirts and reinforcement at the oil pan flange. The new engine block helped reduce engine vibration and unwanted noise while providing refined performance. Both engines featured piston skirts coated with a [[teflon]]-based friction-reducing material, and fitted with low-tension, low oil consumption rings. In addition, a new fail-safe cooling mode provided protection even in the case of a catastrophic coolant loss (such as a punctured radiator). In the event of coolant loss, the engine control unit shuts off fuel to alternate [[Engine cylinder|cylinders]] to reduce the risk of engine damage from overheating. The valves continue to operate, in order to pump cooling air through the cylinders. The cooling system was designed to maintain an ideal engine temperature even when subjected to a prolonged 15 percent [[gradient]] in 46 °C (115 °F) weather. A returnless fuel supply system helped to reduce evaporative emissions by providing consistent pressure to the [[fuel injector]]s through a high-pressure pump. New active [[hydraulic]] engine mounts were introduced to prevent the powertrain from inducing vibrations into the chassis. By optimizing these engine mounts, the engine block can act as a mass damper, absorbing chassis resonance, improving ride comfort. Expedition's passenger cabin was better sealed than before, in an effort to eliminate intrusive outside noise from reaching the occupants. Wind, powertrain, road and vehicle body noise was reduced by improving interior [[acoustics]] through new [[damping]] materials, a total of 10 shear-style isolating body mounts, heavier sealing of body and panels, redesigned rubber door seals, and extensive use of interior structural acoustic foam in the upper B-pillars, upper and lower D-pillars and floor pan. Road noise was reduced by 2 [[decibels]], body air leakage reduced by 56 percent, chances for sealant noise disturbances reduced from 15 percent to less than 0.5 percent and wind noise measured at {{convert|80|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}} was reduced from 35 [[sones]] to a world class level of 29 sones. The Expedition also received a thorough exterior and interior cosmetic redesign. Expedition featured an all-new front fascia, grille work, headlamps, body trim, rear fascia, tail lamps and liftgate. Interior fit and finish were improved with an all-new interior featuring new dash, door panels, genuine aluminium trim, and plush carpeting. Premium perforated [[leather]] seating surfaces were standard on Expedition ''Eddie Bauer'' (optional on Expedition ''XLT''). Expedition ''FX4'' models featured all of Expedition's optional off-road equipment as standard equipment. Expedition's [[drag coefficient]] was 0.41 Cd.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2003/2003_expedition_1.html |title=2003 Ford Expedition Specifications |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-27}} Three-row seating was standard with all-new manual fold-flat stow away third row seats. No longer did owners have to remove the third rows seats for more storage. The third row could simply "disappear" into the floor. Power assisted PowerFold fold-flat third row seating was available as an optional extra. Available features included in-dash [[CD-ROM]] based [[navigation system]], [[DVD]] based rear entertainment system, [[ultrasonic sensor|ultrasonic]] rear park assist/back up sensors, power [[moon roof]], power adjustable accelerator and brake pedals (introduced on the first generation Expedition), Gentex auto dimming electrochromatic rear view mirror, [[Turn signals#Side marker lights and reflectors|lane departure indicators]] on side-view mirrors, second-row captain's chair luxury seating, premium audiophile sound system with in-dash six-disc [[CD changer]] and rear [[subwoofer]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2003/2003_expedition_2.html |title=2002 Ford Expedition Special Features |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-27}} and four-wheel independent [[pneumatic]] air-ride suspension system. ===Engine(s)=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Model year ! Type/model ! Power ! Torque |- | 2003–2004 | 4.6 Liter (281 cu in) 16-valve [[SOHC]] [[Ford Modular|''Triton'' V-8]] [[gasoline]] | {{convert|232|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|291|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |- | 2003–2004 | 5.4 Liter (330 cu in) 16-valve SOHC ''Triton'' V-8 gasoline/e85 | {{convert|260|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|350|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |- | 2005–2006 | 5.4 Liter (330 cu in) 24-valve SOHC [[Variable Cam Timing|VCT]] ''Triton'' V-8 gasoline | {{convert|300|hp|kW|0|abbr=on}} | {{convert|365|lbft|Nm|0|abbr=on}} |} ===Transmission(s)=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Model Year ! Type/model |- | 2003–2004 | 4-speed 4R70W [[Automatic transmission|automatic]] |- | 2005–2006 | 4-speed 4R75E automatic |} ===Safety and security=== Like the generation before, a 2 air bag [[Supplementary Restraint System|supplementary restraint system]] (SRS) with 2-way occupant protection was standard on Expedition. The dual front SRS air bags now included the Personal Safety System (PSS). PSS would tailor air bag deployment for driver and first passenger and included occupant classification, seat position, crash severity, safety belt pretensioner, load-limiting retractor and safety belt buckle usage [[sensors]]. A new optional 4 air bag supplementary restraint system (SRS) with 6-way occupant protection was also available. This new air bag system included ''SafetyCanopy'' [[Side curtain airbag|dual side curtain air bags]] for head, upper torso and rollover protection. SafetyCanopy would deploy along the A, B and C-pillars down to the vehicle's [[beltline (automotive)|beltline]]. SafetyCanopy could remain inflated after deployment for extended protection and replaced the dual front side airbags featured on the first-generation Expedition. Other features included side-intrusion door beams, security approach lamps, [[SecuriLock]] with smart key and engine immobilizer, BeltMinder, three-point safety belts for all rows of seating, post-crash fuel pump shut-off, [[tire pressure monitoring system]] (TPMS) and four-wheel, four-[[sensor]], four-channel anti-lock braking system (ABS) with [[electronic brakeforce distribution]] (EBD) and [[emergency brake assist]] (EBA). ''AdvanceTrac'' [[electronic stability control]] with [[traction control system]] was introduced as an optional extra. The electronic traction and stability mitigation system would expand to include ''roll stability control'' (RSC) for the 2005 model year. {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan=4| [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration|NHTSA]] [[NHTSA NCAP|NCAP]] crash scores:{{cite web|url=http://www.safercar.gov/portal/site/safercar/menuitem.13dd5c887c7e1358fefe0a2f35a67789/?vgnextoid=4ecd2bc586d7a110VgnVCM1000002fd17898RCRD |title=Home | National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) |publisher=Safercar.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} |- !colspan=2 | MY2003–2005 !colspan=2 | MY2006 |- | Frontal driver: | {{Rating|5|5}} | Frontal driver: | {{Rating|5|5}} |- | Frontal passenger: | {{Rating|5|5}} | Frontal passenger: | {{Rating|5|5}} |- | Side Driver: | Not tested | Side driver: | Not tested |- | Side rear passenger: | Not tested | Side rear passenger: | Not tested |- | Rollover [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/resistance Resistance] ([[Rear-wheel-drive|RWD]]): | Not tested | Rollover Resistance ([[Rear-wheel-drive|RWD]]): | {{Rating|3|5}} |- | Rollover Resistance ([[4WD]]): | Not tested | Rollover Resistance ([[4WD]]): | {{Rating|4|5}} |} ===Model year changes=== ====2003==== Before the 2003 model year ended, Ford updated the running boards on Expeditions equipped with the Eddie Bauer trim. Earlier in the model year, Eddie Bauer models had received standard black running boards. Toward the end of the model year, Arizona beige running boards were re-introduced to complement the Arizona beige body work which came standard on Eddie Bauer. Body colored running boards had previously been offered on the first-generation Expedition from 2000 to 2002. ====2004==== No major cosmetic or mechanical changes. The Expedition ''Eddie Bauer Premier'' model is reintroduced after being absent from the 2003 model trim line-up. Monochromatic paint work with blacked-out headlamps and special alloy wheels were standard on Eddie Bauer Premier versions. A new Expedition ''XLT Sport'' model is added with Dark Shadow grey exterior body trim. The ''FX4'' trim level was renamed ''NBX''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2004/2004_expedition.html |title=2004 FORD EXPEDITION OVERVIEW |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} ====2005==== Expedition received new roof rails which replaced the traditional sliding cross-bar roof racks. A new high end ''Limited'' trim level replaced the Eddie Bauer Premier model (though the regular Eddie Bauer was still available) and featured chrome accented roof rails, chrome-clad aluminium wheels, PowerFold power assisted stowable side view mirrors and chrome tipped exhaust. An upper high end ''King Ranch'' trim level with Castano leather seating was also introduced. The base 4.6 liter Triton V8 engine was dropped for the 2005 model year as the 5.4-liter Triton V8 was made standard on all Expeditions and updated with [[multi-valve|24-valve]] technology and [[variable valve timing]]. Along with the 2005 model V8 engine update, the Expedition also received a significantly updated version of the four-speed 4R70W automatic transmission. The new four-speed automatic transmission, now called 4R75E, featured fully electronic Smart Shift technology. A turbine speed [[sensor]] improved transmission control and provided the basis for the fully electronic shift scheduling. The transmission's [[microprocessor]] speeds were improved for better responsiveness and precision of the control system. The transmission was continuously learning, and would calculate the torque in the next gear and schedule shift points based on the Expedition's projected performance in the next gear.{{cite web |url=http://www.meadowlandford.com/ford-transmission-specs.htm |title=New Ford Transmission Specs |publisher=Meadowlandford.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090623071741/http://meadowlandford.com/ford-transmission-specs.htm |archivedate=2009-06-23 |df= }} For 2005 model Expeditions the 4R75E transmission is designated by the letter "'''B'''" on the manufacturers safety compliance certification label, located in the driver's-side doorjamb. For 2006 model Expeditions, the 4R75E transmission is designated by the letter "'''Q'''". ====2006==== No major cosmetic or mechanical changes. Last year model for the U222. The Gentex auto dimming rear view mirrors were updated. Two new exterior colors were added later on within the model year. They were Pewter metallic and Dark Copper metallic. Medium Flint grey interior was also added to Limited models later on within the model year. Chrome tipped exhaust was made standard on King Ranch models. 2006 would be the last year model for the NBX trim. The ultrasonic rear park assist and SafetyCanopy side curtain airbags were offered as standalone options. Adjustable headrests were also added to the front seats to replace the one piece units.{{cite web|url=http://www.ford-trucks.com/specs/2006/2006_ford_expedition.html |title=2006 Ford Expedition |publisher=Ford-trucks.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-11}} ===Russian Москва-Чукотка (Moscow-Chukotka) overland expedition=== On April 12, 2006, three second-generation full-size Ford Expedition ''Eddie Bauer'' vehicles completed a 32-day overland expedition. This was a {{convert|28000|mi|km|adj=on}} trip across [[North Asia]] and the [[Arctic]] [[Tundra]]. Six team members consisted of leaders, Alexey Mikhailov and Alexander Borodin, technical director, Andrey Rodionov, and professional off-road drivers,: Sergey Goryachev, Victor Parshikov, and Alexey Simakin. The route took them on [[permafrost]] and crossed the [[Arctic Circle]] twice. Visited landmarks included where American aviator [[Carl Ben Eielson]] was lost, and the birthplace of Russian explorer [[Semyon Dezhnev]]. The northernmost point on the route was latitude 69°42′ North ([[Pevek]]). The easternmost point visited was longitude 169°40′ West ([[Cape Dezhnev]]). Temperatures reached -36 °C (-32 °F) and the team encountered [[Whiteout (weather)|whiteouts]] and a [[polar cyclone]]. An estimated 200 kg (440 lbs) of snow was removed from each of the vehicles on the following day.{{cite web |url=http://www.moscow-chukotka.com/eng/ |title=Москва-Чукотка Overland Expedition |publisher=moscow-chukotka.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002075104/http://www.moscow-chukotka.com/eng/ |archivedate=2013-10-02 |df= }} The vehicles were modified with front end guards along with front and rear utility bumpers, [[winches]], safari roof racks, high-powered off-road lights and extra underbody plating for the engines. Two of the vehicles towed a dual axle [[Trailer (vehicle)|utility trailer]]. Two were equipped also with [[caterpillar track]] systems supplied by [[Mattracks]]. The rubber track systems were only used when off-road conditions became too demanding for [[Tire|conventional tires]]. The rear stabilizer bar failed on both vehicles fitted with the Mattracks system. The vehicles were also equipped with gas stoves (to prepare food) and high-capacity auxiliary fuel tanks (mounted in the rear cargo bay) and sometimes run on poor-quality [[gasoline]].{{cite web|url=http://carsellers.ru/news/article/2639/ |title=Ford проложил трассу "Москва-Чукотка" |publisher=Carsellers.ru |date=2006-04-26 |accessdate=2010-07-27}} =={{anchor|Third generation}} Third generation (2007–2017)== {{Infobox automobile |name=Third generation (U324) |image=Ford-Expedition-Eddie-Bauer.jpg |aka=Ford Expedition Special Service Vehicle |production=August 2, 2006–July 2, 2017 |model_years=2007–2017 |engine=5.4 L ''[[Ford Triton engine#3-valve 2|Triton 24V]]'' [[V8 engine|V-8]] (2006–2014)
3.5 L ''[[Ford EcoBoost engine#3.5-L|EcoBoost]]'' V-6 (2014–2017) |wheelbase= {{convert|119.0|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |length= {{convert|206.5|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |width={{convert|78.8|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |height=SWB: {{convert|77.2|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
Eddie Bauer: {{convert|78.3|in|mm|0|abbr=on}} |transmission=6-speed 6R75 [[Automatic transmission|automatic]]
6-speed 6R80 automatic
6-speed 6R80 ''[[Manumatic|SelectShift]]'' automatic
